V muzeju učijo tudi hojo na hoduljah
V Rogatcu je največji slovenski muzej na prostem. Nekatere objekte so prenesli iz bližnjih vasi.
05 Nov 2019, 16:25 by Primož Hieng



Toplar



To je prava etno vasica. FOTO: Tomo Jeseničnik



Prikaz mlačve s cepci



Ko se peče kruh, je veselje v hiši.



Trgovina na drobno Lodn


ROGATEC – Muzej na prostem v Rogatcu prikazuje originalno stavbno in krajinsko dediščino širšega območja tega dela Slovenije. K tem muzejem, ki jim pravijo tudi skansen, lahko prištejemo še muzej na prostem Pleterje na Dolenjskem, Deželo kozolcev v Šentrupertu na Dolenjskem in ohranjene kašče iz Tuhinjske doline pri gradu Zaprice v Kamniku, ki ga upravlja Medobčinski muzej Kamnik. Zagotovo bi našli še kak manjši muzejski kompleks na prostem.»Jedro rogaškega muzeja na prostem z originalnimi stavbami je z leti preraslo v največji slovenski muzej na prostem in kulturni spomenik državnega pomena,« pravijo na Zavodu za kulturo, turizem in razvoj Rogatec (ZKTRR).
Nominiran za evropski muzej leta
»Leta 1997 je bil nominiran za evropski muzej leta. Bogata programska dejavnost omogoča obiskovalcu, da kulturno izročilo nekdanjih graditeljev spoznava in raziskuje ter doživi svojo lastno izkušnjo dediščine. Muzej si lahko ogledajo invalidi na


To je prava etno vasica. FOTO: Tomo Jeseničnik

vozičkih, saj smo pri urejanju mislili tudi na njih,« še pojasnjujejo. V Muzeju na prostem Rogatec ob vznožju Donačke gore v avtentični štajerski krajini ohranjajo srednještajersko ljudsko stavbarstvo subpanonskega tipa, značilno za Obsotelje od 19. do sredine 20. stoletja. Gručasto razporejeni stanovanjski, gospodarski in obrtniški objekti so res avtentični in vse skupaj je videti kot etno vasica. »Tu se boste dejansko preselili za 100 do 200 let v preteklost, spoznali bivanjske in delovne navade tistega časa in občudovali objekte, ki so jih takrat gradili iz povsem lokalnih naravnih materialov ter s posebnim občutkom za funkcionalnost in estetiko,« pojasnijo na rogaškem zavodu.
Rojstna hiša pesnika Jožeta Šmita
»Nekateri objekti so originalni in so bili preneseni v muzej iz bližnjih vasi, nekateri pa so rekonstruirani po vzoru obstoječih okoliških stavb. Muzej sestavljajo stanovanjska hiša, gospodarsko poslopje (hlev), svinjak, čudovit kozolec iz leta 1892, stranišče na štrbunk in tipični panonski vodnjak. Nekoliko novejše so kovačnica, trgovina na drobno Lodn, viničarska hiša (hiša iz vinograda) in čebelnjak. Objekti in njihova notranjost so taki, kot so bili nekoč, zelena okolica je zgledno urejena, pogled na strmo Donačko goro pa enkraten.« Kot prvi objekt so na zdajšnje mesto leta 1981 postavili stanovanjsko hišo, ki je še vedno osrednji objekt muzeja. Pripadala je Šmitovi družini iz Tlak in je bila v celoti prenesena na območje muzeja. V tej hiši se je rodil slovenski pesnik in prevajalec Jože Šmit. V celoti je izdelana iz lesa in krita s slamnato streho. Stene so ometane z ilovico in prebeljene z apnom. Tla so ilovnata.
Kozolec iz leta 1892
Gospodarsko poslopje je zidano v nadstropje. Namenjeno je bilo različnim namenom: v levem delu je bila vinska klet, nad njo pa pod, kjer so s cepci mlatili žito. V desnem delu je bil hlev. V hiši je bil ilovnat pod, štala je imela lesene podnice, delno tudi zato, da so hlev lažje čistili. Na sprednjem delu so late kot v kozolcu, ob sprednji steni je stiskalnica za grozdje.


Prikaz mlačve s cepci

Kozolci so slovenska posebnost. V Rogatcu stoji najpopolnejši tip – dvojni kozolec ali toplar. Namenjen je bil sušenju sena in drugih pridelkov, tudi koruze, pod njim so kmetje spravljali vozove in razno orodje. Kozolec v muzeju je bil postavljen leta 1892, o čemer priča vrezana letnica na tramu, v vasi Prišlin na Hrvaškem. Posebnost so podporne rozete. Izdelane so v obliki stiliziranih S-linij in okrašene s šesterokotnimi rozetami – enako kot nosilni tram v hiši.V svinjaku je prostora za štiri prašiče, v podaljšku je listnica. Sprednji del nadstropja ima late kot kozolec. V pokritem hodniku se še danes suši slama za popravljanje slamnatih streh. Na latah se suši repno in korenjevo listje za borno prehrano svinj pozimi. Svinjak, ki je razstavljen v muzeju, so zgradili v 50. letih prejšnjega stoletja po tradicionalni zasnovi.
Brez poslikanih panjskih končnic
Čebelarstvo je vedno imelo pomembno vlogo v življenju Slovencev. Med so uporabljali kot sladilo, zdravilo in pomirjevalo. Iz voska so delali sveče. Iz medu so pekli pecivo in pripravljali različne pijače. Tudi Rogatec ima bogato čebelarsko tradicijo. Med obema vojnama je bila tukaj lectarija. Že v 19. stoletju je samostojen čebelnjak postal sestavni del kmetije. Na tem območju pod Donačko goro se do druge svetovne vojne niso uveljavili sicer po preostali Sloveniji razširjeni panji kranjiči, zato bi tu zaman iskali poslikane panjske končnice.


Ko se peče kruh, je veselje v hiši.

»Samo ogledovanje objektov je veliko premalo, da bi podrobneje spoznali življenje in delo nekoč,« še dodajajo na Zavodu za kulturo, turizem in razvoj Rogatec. »V muzeju je zato poskrbljeno za organizirano vodenje, ob tem pa izvajamo zanimiv pedagoški program aktivnih etnoloških delavnic za mladino in odrasle, muzejske demonstracije in učne delavnice domačih obrti, kmečkih opravil in kulturnega izročila, kot so peka kruha, pletenje iz ličja in šibja, ročno tkanje, kovaštvo, kamnoseštvo, kuhanje in lupljenje vrbovega šibja, velikonočne butare in košarice iz testa, božične šprudle, piščali iz lubja in hoja na hoduljah.«

1981.so v muzeju najprej postavili hišo.
Tu se boste preselili za 100 do 200 let v preteklost.

The museum also teaches walking on stilts
Rogatec is Slovenia's largest open-air museum. Some of the objects were transferred from nearby villages.
05 Nov 2019, 16:25 by Primoz Hieng



Toplar



It's a real ethno village. PHOTO: Tomo Jesenicnik

Retail Lodn


ROGATEC - The open-air museum in Rogatec shows the original architectural and landscape heritage of the wider area of this part of Slovenia. These museums, which are also called skansen, include the Pleterje open air museum in Dolenjska, the Land of hayracks in Šentrupert in Dolenjska and the preserved granaries from the Tuhinj valley near the Castle of Zaprice in Kamnik, managed by the Kamnik Intermunicipal Museum. "The core of the Rogaška open-air museum with original buildings has grown over the years into the largest Slovenian open-air museum and a cultural monument of national importance," says the Rogatec Institute for Culture, Tourism and Development (ZKTRR). .
Nominated for European Museum of the Year
“In 1997, he was nominated for the European Museum of the Year. The rich program activity enables the visitor to get to know and explore the cultural heritage of former builders and experience their own heritage experience. The museum can be viewed by disabled people at


It's a real ethno village. PHOTO: Tomo Jesenicnik

trolleys, because we were thinking of them when editing, "they explain. At the foot of the Donačka gora in the authentic Styrian landscape, the Rogatec Open-Air Museum preserves the mid-Styrian folk architecture of the sub-Pannonian type, typical of the Obsotelje region from the 19th to the middle of the 20th century. The clustered residential, commercial and artisanal buildings are truly authentic and all look like an ethno village. "You will actually move here for 100 to 200 years in the past, get to know the living and working habits of that time and admire the buildings that were then constructed from purely local natural materials and with a special sense of functionality and aesthetics," the Rogaška Institute explains.
Birthplace of the poet Joze Schmidt
“Some of the buildings are original and have been transferred to a museum from nearby villages, while some have been reconstructed following the existing surrounding buildings. The museum consists of a dwelling house, outbuilding (shed), a hog, a beautiful hayrack dating from 1892, a toilet on a stubble and a typical Pannonian fountain. Somewhat new are the blacksmith shop, the Lodn retail store, the winery (the vineyard house) and the bee house. The buildings and their interiors are what they used to be, the green surroundings are exemplarily landscaped and the views of the steep Donetsk Mountain unique. ”In 1981, the first building was erected as an apartment building, which is still the central object of the museum. It belonged to the Schmidt family from Tlak and was completely transferred to the area of the museum. The Slovenian poet and translator Jože Šmit was born in this house. It is entirely made of wood and covered with a thatched roof. The walls are plastered with loam and whitewashed with lime. The soil is loamy.
1892 hayrack
The outbuilding is built upstairs. It was used for different purposes: in the left part was a wine cellar, and above it was a floor where the grains were ground with splinters. To the right was a stable. The house had a loamy floor, the barn had wooden floors, partly to make the house easier to clean. On the front they are as late as in a hayrack, along the front wall is a grape press.


Display of slugs with splitters

Glasses are a Slovenian specialty. In Rogatec there is the most complete type - double hayrack or toplar. It was intended for drying hay and other crops, including maize, under which farmers used to put carts and various tools. The museum's hayrack was erected in 1892, as evidenced by the engraved vintage on a beam, in the village of Prislin, Croatia. A special feature is the support rosettes. They are made in the form of stylized S-lines and decorated with hexagonal rosettes - the same as the carrier beam in the house. There is room for four pigs in the sow, in the extension there is a wallet. The front of the floor has latex as a hayrack. Straw roofs are still drying in the covered hallway today to repair thatched roofs. The tail and root foliage are dried on the lats for winter boar consumption. The pig, which is on display in the museum, was built in the 1950s following a traditional design.
No painted hive endings
Beekeeping has always played an important role in the lives of Slovenes. Honey was used as a sweetener, medicine and sedative. They made candles from the wax. They made pastries from honey and made various drinks. Rogatec also has a rich beekeeping tradition. During the two wars there was a lectarium here. As early as the 19th century, an independent apiary became an integral part of the farm. In the area under Donacka gora, hives were not established until the Second World War.


When bread is baked, there is joy in the house.

"Just viewing the objects is far too small to get to know life and work in the past," Rogatec added at the Institute for Culture, Tourism and Development. "The museum therefore provides organized management, and we carry out an interesting pedagogical program of active ethnological workshops for youth and adults, museum demonstrations and educational workshops of local crafts, farm chores and cultural traditions such as bread baking, knitting of lychee and wicker, hand-weaving, blacksmithing, stonemasonry, willow-willow cooking and peeling, Easter butters and dough baskets, Christmas scrubs, bark beetles and walking on stilts. "
